subject: Cleanup dhcp namespace upon dhcp setup.
commit_message:
Cleanup dhcp namespace upon dhcp setup.

In some cases when more than 1 DHCP agents were assigned
to a network and then they became dead, their DHCP ports
become reserved. Later, when those agents revive or start
again, they acquire reserved ports, but it's not guaranteed
that they get exactly same ports. In such case DHCP agent
may create interface in the namespaces despite that another
interface already exist. In such case there will be two
hosts with dhcp namespaces each containing duplicate ports,
e.g. one port will be present on two hosts. This breaks
DHCP.

Closes-Bug: #1509959
Change-Id: I34eb1ad5c44dd3528c9910462e26536186e7a4fb

subject: Add Magnum config for default network driver per COE

Add Magnum config for default network driver per COE

Problem description:
Magnum should provide support for configuration of default network drivers per
COE. An example use case could be a cloud operator who would like to have
control of what default container network driver should be used on a per-COE
basis. The cloud operator in this case should be able to set the default
network driver per COE in /etc/magnum/magnum.conf.

Proposed fix:
Add 3 configuration list options to the config in /etc/magnum/magnum.conf:
- kubernetes_default_network_driver

- swarm_default_network_driver
  (default='docker')
- mesos_default_network_driver
  (default='docker')
When a baymodel is created and the --network-driver attribute is not supplied,
then the configured default network driver for the selected COE will first be
checked against the list of allowed network drivers for that COE, and if
allowed, the configured default network driver will be used for the new
baymodel.

libvirt: Handle mismatch of volume information between BDM and domain XML

There is a case that the volume information is deleted from BDM
but the information remains on domain XML of Libvirt when user
detaches a volume from an instance if OS is hang up and so on.
If the volume is attached via iSCSI, currently iSCSI connection

domain XML and remove detached device from the list.

subject: Add new Connector APIs for path validation
commit_message:
Add new Connector APIs for path validation

The purpose of this patch is to add new APIs to os-brick Connector objects
to see how we can help validate the discovered volumes.  By adding a few
new APIs into the Connectors, we can ask the Connector objects to give us
a list of paths on the system that are associated with a volume.
Then after doing a disconnect, which happens during nova live migration
as well as normal volume detaches, we can fetch the list of all volumes, and
make sure the original volume paths don't exist in the list of all
volumes for that type.  Therefore verifying that when a volume
is removed, it doesn't leave any paths on the system behind.

This patch adds the following new APIs to the Connector objects:
 * get_volume_paths() - fetch a list of paths on the system for a volume.
 * get_search_path() - get the path on the host where the Connector looks for
                       volumes.
 * get_all_available_volumes() - Get the entire list of volumes in the search
                                 path for the given protocol type (iSCSI, FC)

Cinder Spec:
  https://review.openstack.org/#/c/204180/

Implements: blueprint brick-fetch-paths

commit_message:
Correct the computation of elapsed time while waiting for state change

The computation of elapsed time and present time during waiting for
state change is incorrect. This change simplifies the code and
corrects that error.

There is a subtle change in behavior also introduced as part of this
change. Earlier code would unconditionally wait for WAIT_TIME before
checking status. The proposed code will immediately poll status.

A configuration parameter has been added for the WAIT_TIME with the
former default value of 3.

The change(s) to test_dbaas (the tests) are because of an unfortunate
side-effect of the old code. The tests would just mock sleep() but
the old code would advance the amount of time waited by whatever time
they thought they'd have waited for. This meant that the
wait_for_real_status_to_change_to method would take approximately no
time in tests but would appear to do all the right things. However,
since the new code is using time.time() to deterime how long it's been
around has caused the mock'ing of sleep() to have an unexpected
result; the wait_for_real_status_to_change_to method becomes a CPU
hog! The hack I've used is to fake time with a side_effect that
advances at 1 'second' per call.

commit_message:
Add retry for tgtadm update when tgt exists

For target creation using tgtadm driver, we create a persistence
file for the target, then send a tgt-admin --update 'name' where
name is the specific persistence file we want to read in and update
from.

It turns out that we can hit race conditions where the persistence
file is written, and an update is requested but target has already
done work to make it believe that the target has already been created.

One thought was to just use "update ALL" but this still seems to have
issues, and changes the error to an account exists failure.

This patch takes the brute force approach and adds a retry to the
update command.

Added CORS support to Nova

This adds the CORS support middleware to Nova, allowing a deployer
to optionally configure rules under which a javascript client may
break the single-origin policy and access the API directly.

The paste.ini method of deploying the middleware was
chosen, because it needs to be able to annotate responses created

keystone would reject the request before the cross-domain headers
could be annotated, resulting in an error response that was
unreadable by the user agent.

The test suite was expanded, to permit the inclusion of

subject: WIP - Add Group Based Policy Project
commit_message:
WIP - Add Group Based Policy Project

Group Based Policy (GBP) [1] is a policy framework for cloud infrastructure.
It is based on declarative, intent-based abstractions that build on existing
OpenStack interfaces to enable scalable automation.

GBP is currently an Open Source stackforge project. It was originally
conceived and presented during the OpenStack Icehouse Design Summit, Hong Kong,
in Nov 2013 [2]. It has evolved through discussions that happened in the
subsequent design summits [3][4], in weekly IRC meetings since Dec 2013 [5],
mailing list discussions in openstack-dev, in #openstack-gbp, and coding
sprints [6].

GBP has an elected PTL [7] and a core team of ten reviewers [8] who were chosen
based on their design and code contributions to the project. The project follows
standard OpenStack practices with designs being discussed in gerrit specs [8],
public code reviews [10], bugs tracked in Launchpad, a test-driven gate, and
stable branches. The project has a diverse set of contributors spanning
many organizations [11].

GBP leverages other OpenStack services such as Keystone, Neutron,
Nova, Heat, Horizon, and aims to integrate with other services to
comprehensively manage and automate policy enforcement across infrastructure
components. The project has designated liaisons [12] to help collaborate with
other project teams and keep GBP in sync with the rest of the ecosystem.

GBP has an extensible architecture that allows for plugging in open source and
vendor policy drivers. It integrates with the OpenDaylight Network Controller,
and three other vendor backends, with others being planned. GBP has its own
client package, and also UI and automation packages, that plug into Horizon and
Heat respectively. GBP Juno release is available with packages for Fedora, Red
Hat, Ubuntu, and also devstack-based install for developers [13].

fix fuzzy search for same-distance case

get_fuzzy_matches() cannot handle case where all
commands have the same Levenshtein distance
from searched command. It will bomb-out with
IndexError (dist[i][1] referencing one element
after the end).

It also does not handle no-commands case or
the case where searched command is the prefix of
all commands. The latter two cases are minor, since
'help' and 'complete' commands are always present.

We fix it by iterating over the partial result
safely, consuming only candidates with distance==0
(prefix commands) and those of the same minimum
distance.

subject: Shorten the kolla job names
commit_message:
Shorten the kolla job names

Due to the length of the job name and the tox target we run into an
uncommon limitation; the virtualenv that tox launches is nested in a
path that is too long. This leads to an error on our longest named
job which prevents tox from running properly.

This limitation is the limit for the line length of the first line
in a shell script. In this case <virtualenv>/bin/pip has a path that
exceeds that limit by a few characters. This results in a very
confusing "OSError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory" error.

See `man execve` for more info. A quote from that manpage:
'A maximum line length of 127 characters is allowed for the first line
in a #! executable shell script.'

To reproduce this locally you can just create a very long path and
then run tox in it. Example: http://paste.openstack.org/show/478559/

Change-Id: I51f8f67d9ab139f1d539fce05ce3cc4766aeedff

subject: Allow DHCP responses to reach clients.
commit_message:
Allow DHCP responses to reach clients.

When security groups were first implemented in this plugin, I had to put
a hack in our custom branch of OVS that made DHCP packets bypass
conntrack.  This issue has now been debugged and fixed.

Part of this patch is switching our default OVS branch to one without
the DHCP hack. We still require a custom branch because we need patches
for the kernel backport of ovs+conntrack integration.  This backport is
up for review so we should be back to OVS master soon.

The first part of the DHCP problem was a bug in ovs conntrack
integration that resulted in the DHCP request not making it to the DHCP
server at all in some cases.  The fix is here:

    https://github.com/openvswitch/ovs/commit/e37b8437e915a02a88116e5ea7af1a7e716bd597

The second part of the DHCP problem is that because of how DHCP works,
it's not a point to point connection that can be tracked and
automatically let responses through.  Instead, we need to explicitly
allow DHCP server responses to reach clients.  This is likely temporary
and can be removed once OVN's native DHCP support is merged.

Add OpenID Connect RP Apache Module

This patch set adds bits to configure the OpenID Connect
relying party apache module.

There were a few changes in the logic to make this work.

* keystone_federated_auth_methods variable was added so the

  is a list of saml implementations that is used to apply the

  supported.

  then apply the Shibboleth apache configs. Now, the variables
  mentioned above will help with deciding which apache configs to
  apply.

* The mod_auth_openidc module uses the memcached servers to for
  caching data to use across multiple keystone nodes.

Other changes:

* Added example trusted_idp_list entry for the google OIDC server.

* Moved the keystone_sp docs to user_variables.yml

* Loading keystone_sp facts earlier in the playbooks.
